lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Jorge Amselle (Op-Ed, May 6) looks at the debate over the bilingual ballot measure in California in the wrong way. The question isn't whether bilingual education, as currently delivered, is the best of all possible programs -- no one would seriously make that argument -- but rather who should decide whether and what kind of bilingual education is offered. Should there be local control or centralized rule-making?
abstract: University of California at Berkeley Dean David L Kirp letter on Jorge Amselle's May 6 article holds California Education Board move to let local school boards decide whether and what bilingual education programs to offer should be more appealing to conservatives than ballot initiative to ban programs; drawing
